The McCarrick scandal created a crisis of credibility for the church, primarily because there was evidence Vatican and U.S. church leaders knew he slept with seminarians but turned a blind eye as McCarrick rose to the top of the U.S. church as an adept fundraiser who advised three popes.

The Vatican’s report on its investigation put the lion’s share of blame on a dead saint: Pope John Paul II, who appointed McCarrick archbishop of Washington, D.C., in 2000, despite having commissioned an inquiry that confirmed he slept with seminarians.

The report found that John Paul believed McCarrick’s last-minute, handwritten denial: “I have made mistakes and may have sometimes lacked in prudence, but in the seventy years of my life I have never had sexual relations with any person, male or female, young or old, cleric or lay,” McCarrick wrote.

title: Obama expresses deep concern as Trump admin takes aim at students and law firms
summary: Former President Barack Obama said he is "deeply concerned" with some of the actions that President Donald Trump and his administration have taken and seemed to call out the Republican Party for not pushing back on them.
story: Former President Barack Obama said he is "deeply concerned" with some of the actions that President Donald Trump and his administration have taken and seemed to call out the Republican Party for not pushing back on them.

Obama rebuked Trump without explicitly naming him over the federal government's threats against universities and students who exercise free speech, its targeting of law firms, and the new tariffs imposed on foreign countries.

"I don’t think what we just witnessed in terms of economic policy and tariffs is going to be good for America, but that’s a specific policy," Obama said in his remarks at Hamilton College in New York. "I’m more deeply concerned with a federal government that threatens universities if they don’t give up students who are exercising their right to free speech," he said.

Obama said he's more troubled by a White House that takes aim at law firms that represent ideas or parties that its occupants disagree with, and that the administration has punished media outlets. Trump has signed executive orders penalizing major law firms and lawyers, prompting outrage within the legal community. The White House has also barred The Associated Press from coverage over its refusal to refer to the Gulf of Mexico as the Gulf of America.
"That kind of behavior is contrary to the basic compact we have as Americans," he said.
Obama suggested that Republicans would be outraged if he had done similar things as president.

"Imagine if I had pulled Fox News’ credentials from the White House press corps," he said, adding, “It’s unimaginable that the same parties that are silent now would have tolerated behavior like that from me or a whole bunch of my predecessors."
He added, "I say this not on a partisan basis. This has to do with something more precious, which is who are we as a country and what values do we stand for?"

His final message during his speech was that "history zigs and zags and there are times of conflict and there are times of stupidity and there are times of danger," but he wants people to remain resilient.
"Don’t get discouraged," he said. "I know it’s a little crazy right now, but we’re going to be OK."

Former Vice President Kamala Harris also spoke out against the Trump administration at the Leading Women Defined Summit in California on Thursday. She said that the country is witnessing "progress being rolled back" and a "sense of fear" taking hold nationwide.

"We are seeing those who are capitulating to clearly unconstitutional threats," she said. "And these are the things that we are witnessing each day in these last few months in our country. And it understandably creates a great sense of fear."
Harris, who has kept a low profile since losing to Trump in November's presidential election, said that "fear has a way of being contagious" but that "courage is also contagious."
The White House didn't immediately respond to a request for comment about their remarks.

title: Tufts student grabbed off street by immigration officers scores legal win, has case moved to Vermont
summary: A federal judge ordered the detained Tufts University student Rumeysa Öztürk's petition for her release to be transferred from Massachusetts to Vermont.
story: A federal judge ordered the detained Tufts University student's petition for her release to be transferred from Massachusetts to Vermont.

U.S. District Judge Denise J. Casper for Massachusetts denied the government’s motion to dismiss the petition and its alternative request to transfer it to the Western District of Louisiana, where the student, Rumeysa Öztürk, is currently detained.

The judge said Öztürk's petition “raises serious issues as to the conduct of her arrest and detention as alleged," adding that the case will be transferred to the District of Vermont, where Öztürk was confined overnight at the time that the petition was filed.
Lawyers for Öztürk did not immediately return requests for comment. The Department of Justice declined to comment.
The judge said her order blocking Öztürk from being deported remains in effect unless and until the transferee court orders otherwise.

Öztürk, a doctoral student from Turkey, was arrested by immigration authorities on March 25 in Somerville, Massachusetts. Video of her arrest shows Department of Homeland Security officers in plainclothes surrounding her, grabbing her at her wrists and whisking her away into a nearby SUV as she screamed.
Authorities then moved Öztürk to Louisiana, where several other foreign university students arrested have been taken to in recent weeks.

title: Tina Knowles wishes Beyoncé, Jay Z a happy anniversary: ‘True love rises above all’
summary: Tina Knowles is celebrating 17 years of marriage for Beyoncé and Jay-Z and praises their ability to block out the noice.
story: Tina Knowles is celebrating 17 years of marriage for Beyoncé and Jay-Z.
On April 4, the superstar’s mom shared a video montage of the couple over the years, calling them two of her “favorite people” and praising them for being able to “block out all the outside noises.”

“Happy 17th anniversary to two of my favorite people in the whole wide world!!!!,” Tina Knowles wrote on Instagram, alongside red heart emoji. “Your love and commitment, and the ability to block out all the outside noises is remarkable. True love rises above all the b-------. Enjoy your day.”
The clip includes Beyoncé and Jay-Z embracing, posing together and having sweet moments on and off the stage.

Knowles didn’t elaborate on what the couple have been going through. However, last year, a federal lawsuit was filed against Jay-Z and Sean “Diddy” Combs alleging that they sexually assaulted a 13-year-old girl in 2000. The filing was made by an anonymous accuser, identified only as “Jane Doe.”

Jay-Z responded to the civil lawsuit, denying the allegations in a statement issued on the Roc Nation X account Dec. 8. In the lengthy statement, he touched on how the lawsuit would impact his family, especially his children.

“My only heartbreak is for my family,” he wrote, in part. “My wife and I will have to sit our children down, one of whom is at the age where her friends will surely see the press and ask questions about the nature of these claims and explain the cruelty and greed of people. I mourn yet another loss of innocence.”
“Children should not have to endure such at their young age. It is unfair to have to try to understand inexplicable degrees of malice meant to destroy families and human spirit,” he continued.
The woman dropped her lawsuit against Jay-Z and Diddy in February of this year, according to NBC News.
Beyoncé and Jay-Z secretly got married in 2008 after dating for about seven years.

“What Jay and I have is real. It’s not about interviews or getting the right photo op. It’s real,” Beyoncé told Ellen DeGeneres on her talk show in November 2008, while talking about their relationship. She added that they decided to have a small ceremony because “it’s been my day so many days already.”
The pair have three children together: Blue Ivy Carter, Rumi Carter and Sir Carter.

title: Padma Lakshmi calls out influencers who said South Indian restaurant didn’t deserve its Michelin star
summary: After The VIP List said NYC's South Indian restaurant Semma didn’t deserve its Michelin star, Padma Lakshmi called them out, saying the food is not for them.
story: A scathing TikTok review of an award-winning restaurant is drawing its own criticism from a former “Top Chef” host.

On March 7, when The VIP List (run by Meg Radice and Audrey Jongens), influencers known for their blunt (and often rage-baiting) approach to restaurant reviews, set the internet ablaze with their video on Semma, a Michelin-starred South Indian restaurant in New York City.
The West Village eatery is helmed by chef Vijay Kumar, who recently received a James Beard Foundation nomination for Best Chef: New York State.

“This is why I’ve lost faith in the Michelin system,” the voiceover begins. “Semma is the only Indian restaurant in all of New York with a Michelin star, and here’s the real tea. I could name 15 better Indian restaurants right now, including the biryani cart outside of my apartment.”
The pair gave good marks for the spot’s Mattu Iraichi Sukka and Gunpowder Dosa, but laid into the restaurant’s other offerings.

“I get that this is Southern Indian, so I can’t expect a tiki masala on the menu,” they say, referring to chicken tikka masala, a dish invented by a Pakistani Scottish chef in Glasgow, served at many Indian restaurants in the U.S.
The pair also said everything was “drowned” in a “mystery sauce” that had nearly had them go “full Helen Keller” when it got in their eyes.

“Usually, I’m a whore for oxtail, but I’d close my legs for this,” said the voiceover. They then compared the biryani to Wonder Bread. “Overall, nothing was horrible, but nothing was great either, and I truly do not get the hype. Go cry about it.”
The review was posted on the pair’s Instagram and TikTok, but it didn’t go over well on either platform.
“The pronunciation of biriyani and tikka masala told me all i need to know,” wrote one TikToker.
“She let the racism slip a little in this one,” wrote another.
“Good, keep your followers away from Semma so people with actual taste can get reservations thanks,” commented one person on Instagram.

“Awful, sad take. But, I’m sure you knew that when posting this click bait,” wrote another. “Think Bourdain said it best when talking about people like you: ‘They are the very picture of entitled, negative energy. They’re bad for chefs, they’re bad for restaurants.’”

The lightning rod of a review also caught the attention of TV host, author and food expert Padma Lakshmi, who called it “really annoying” in an April 3 video captioned, “Semma is for us…. And they not like us.”

“I’m pretty sure Michelin doesn’t give a s--- about you, either, or what you think about anything, let alone food,” Lakshmi says. “And just a tip before you go off slagging other cuisines, maybe you should understand them a little bit more, or at least, I don’t know, learn how to pronounce the dishes you’re actually critiquing. I got news for you: There’s no ‘tiki’ anything in Indian cuisine.”

“And by the way, Semma isn’t made for you. It’s not. It’s made for us,” Lakshmi says. “I’m pretty sure that if nobody but desis went there for the rest of its existence, it would still be booked solid for the next decade.”
Commenters ate Lakshmi’s rebuke up: “Imagine having the Queen of spice herself this mad at you, I would retire!!” one wrote.
Meanwhile, the women behind The VIP List say they approach every cuisine with fairness, regardless of “origin or hype,” and that they just weren’t fans of Semma.

“Here’s the thing about taste—it’s subjective,” Radice and Jongens tell TODAY.com. “We all have it, and you don’t need a certification to know what you like (or don’t). That’s kind of the whole point of what we do. You’re welcome to agree with our taste—or not.”

“Social media gives us the freedom to spotlight what we think is great, and call it out when it’s not,” they add. “If we don’t vibe with a place, that’s not a scandal. It’s just content. It’s commentary. It’s satire.”
Regarding Lakshmi, they say they’re fans and think it’s great she added her thoughts to the discussion: “Wasn’t the beef we expected today but we’re here for it.”

title: Tonight's new ‘Dateline’ episode is about the double murder of a Kansas couple
summary: Is there a new episode of Dateline tonight? How to watch the episode revisiting murder of Mike Sisco and Karen Harkness.
story: "Dateline" is back on April 4 on NBC with a new episode, followed by a weekend full of programming.

Reported by Andrea Canning, the "Dateline" team details the 2002 double murder of Mike Sisco and Karen Harkness in an upcoming episode, and how a jury convicted Sisco's ex-wife Dana Chandler for the murders this year.
Keep reading to find out how to watch the newest installment of "Dateline," along with the other installments throughout the weekend.
Is there a new episode of ‘Dateline’ tonight?
Yes. "Dateline" is dropping a brand-new episode on April 4 with an episode titled "Deadly Obsession."
How to watch the latest episode of ‘Dateline’
"Dateline" will air its newest installment on Friday, April 4 at 9 p.m. ET/PT and 8 p.m. CT.
The episode will be released for streaming on Peacock the following day on Saturday, April 5.

On Saturday, "Dateline" is also releasing the"Weekend Mystery" titled "The Streets of Laredo."  The episode drops on NBC at 9 p.m. ET / 8 p.m. CT, and 1:30 a.m. MTN and 1:32 a.m. PT on Sunday morning due to NBC's primetime programming.

On Sunday, April 6, "Dateline" correspondent Josh Mankiewicz reports on the murder of college student Mollie Tibbets in an episode entitled "The Last Mile." The episode premieres on at 10 p.m. ET/PT and 9 p.m. CT on NBC.
What is the story behind tonight’s ‘Dateline’?
"Deadly Obsession," the newest episode of "Dateline," follows the murder of Topeka, Kansas couple Mike Sisco and Karen Harkness.
This March, a jury convicted Dana Chandler, Sisco's ex-wife, of of two counts of murder in the third trial related to Sisco and Harkness’ murders.

Chandler was arrested in 2011, nine years after the murders, and convicted in 2012. The conviction was overturned by the Kansas Supreme Court, who found the prosecutor had lied to the jury. The jury failed to reach a verdict in the second trial in 2022.

The episode features interviews with Mike Sisco’s mother Carol Sisco, daughter Hailey Seel, sister Cathy Boots and brother-in-law Mark Boots; Karen Harkness’ daughter Erin Harkness Sutton and son Chad Harkness; former Topeka police saegeant Richard Volle; Shawnee County District Attorney Mike Kagay; and others.

title: Dave Coulier shares that Bob Saget visits him in his dreams
summary: Doug Coulier talked about how "Full House" co-star Bob Saget visits him in his dreams and makes him laugh.
story: Bob Saget can still make “Full House” co-star Dave Coulier laugh in the unlikeliest of places.
Saget died in 2022 at the age of 65 from head trauma, but Coulier says he’s visited by him in his sleep.
“I miss Bob so much. I truly had a brother (in him). I met Bob when I was 18 years old,” Coulier told Parade.
“And by the way, yes, he comes to me in my dreams, and he always does something silly and foolish and makes me laugh.”

Coulier, 65, has dealt with his own health issues over the last several months, revealing on TODAY in November 2024 that he had been diagnosed with Stage 3 non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Earlier this week, he confirmed to TODAY.com that he is cancer-free. Coulier says he knows that Saget would have gone above and beyond to check in on him while he was sick.

“He would have called me every day: ‘How are you doing? What’s the prognosis, Dave? Tell me what’s going on.’ He would have driven me crazy,” Coulier said. “It was a lovable crazy that he had. I think about him often. I’ll be having a moment of clarity, and I’ll think, ‘Oh, call Bob,’ and then I realize I can’t.”

Coulier and Saget starred on “Full House” for eight seasons from 1987 until 1995 and then reprised their roles as Joey and Danny, respectively, on the Netflix reboot “Fuller House,” which ran for five seasons from 2016 until 2020.

The “Full House” cast was left reeling after Saget died and on the one-year anniversary of his death, Coulier paid tribute to him and their long history together, beginning when they were young comedians.

“Bob could always bring out the 5th grader in me. I met him when I was just an unknown, 18 year-old standup at a small club in Detroit,” he wrote on Instagram, alongside a picture of the two of them on the steps of the San Francisco house the Tanner family called home on “Full House.” “We became instant brothers.

“Sometimes, I still grab my phone, ready to share one of the hundreds of silly bits that we did together. At some point today, I’ll think about how much I miss him and I’ll shed some tears. Then I’ll hear Bob’s voice, and it’ll make me laugh. Enjoy the gifts of life while they’re still here with you. Tell those you love that you love them … and hug them like Bob Saget.”

title: Eminem's daughter Hailie Jade welcomes a baby boy
summary: Eminem's daughter Hailie Jade Mathers welcomed her 1st child, a boy, with husband Evan McClintock.
story: Eminem is a grandfather!
The rapper's daughter Hailie Jade Mathers announced April 4 that she and husband Evan McClintock welcomed their first child last month — and the baby's name honors his Grammy-winning grandpa.

Mathers posted a photo of her newborn son wearing a knitted mint blue hoodie on Instagram. A sign announcing the baby's full name, Elliot Marshall McClintock, and his date of birth — March 14, 2025 —  stands just behind him.
Fans were quick to note that baby Elliot's middle name is a tribute to Eminem, 52, whose real name is Marshall Mathers III.
"His middle name I'm crying. He’s so precious," wrote one.
Elliot's arrival comes a little less than a year after Mathers and McClintock tied the knot in May 2024. The couple announced their engagement in February 2023 after several years of dating.

In October 2024, Eminem hinted that he was about to become a grandfather when he released a music video for his single “Temporary.” One of the video's scenes shows the rap legend's daughter, whose mother is Eminem's ex-wife Kim Scott, giving him a jersey with “Grandpa” and a "No. 1" written on the back.
The video also includes home footage of the father-daughter duo over the years.
Mathers followed up on her dad’s video by posting a photo of her holding a sonogram as she embraced McClintock. She captioned the image, “Mom & dad est. 2025.”
She revealed her baby’s gender during the Oct. 11 episode of her podcast, “Just A Little Shady,” and also shared the sweet story of how she told her dad.
She explained that she gave Eminem the “grandpa” jersey wrapped up as a gift.

“He was first concerned, because he’s like, ‘Well, I didn’t get you a gift,’” she recalled. “And freaked out for a couple minutes. He’s like, ‘We’re supposed to get each other gifts?’ I’m like, ‘No, no, it’s just for the football season.’”

After unwrapping the jersey, Eminem was even more confused. Mathers recalled that when he saw the word “grandpa,” the rapper thought he was being teased as being old. But after his daughter handed him a sonogram image, it all clicked and he was ecstatic.
“I pulled out the ultrasound picture, and he was like, ‘Wait, this is real. Like, this is happening.’”

title: What Jennifer Garner is really like as a friend, according to Judy Greer
summary: What is Jennifer Garner like as a friend? We asked Judy Greer, her costar in 13 going on 30 and The Last Thing He Told Me.
story: Some things never change. In the case of Jennifer Garner and Judy Greer, being co-stars and besties is kind of a lifelong thing.

The pair played best friends 21 years ago in “13 Going on 30"and reunited on-screen for “The Last Thing He Told Me” Season 2, which is anticipated to arrive on Apple TV+ late this year. They also are close friends in real life, Greer says.

“Have you ever worked with one of your best friends? It’s really hard to get anything done,” Greer tells TODAY.com of filming the AppleTV+ show. “When we were at the studio, sometimes we would have to separate ourselves because it’s just too fun.”
“We’ve realized that we have to work together a lot because it’s the best way to hang out,” she adds. “We’re both so busy otherwise.”
Still, they've maintained an off-camera connection over the years, and Greer let us in on the sweet personalized gifts the friends have swapped.

“She bought us these sweatshirts a long time ago that said ‘Jen Garner and Judy Greer,’” she says. “And then I got us ‘JG’ necklaces as like a Christmas present. I don’t know, we’re dorks. We’re friend dorks.”
Just as she's played the spunky best friend in films like “The Wedding Planner” and “27 Dresses,” friendship has been a nonnegotiable priority in Greer's personal life for decades.

“I’d be nothing without my friends,” she says. “I’m a big believer in working to maintain friendships. I think that there’s a lot of focus on romantic relationships, especially when we’re in our 20s and 30s.

“I think that working to maintain our friendships is just as, if not more important,” she adds. “Because in a romantic relationship, you’re around that person, in theory, most days or every day. Friendships you really have to stick to it. You have to keep at it.”
To be a great friend, you have to have great friends. And Greer shares that Garner is exactly the kind of friend everyone needs in their corner.

“She’s exactly the kind of friend you would imagine,” Greer said. “People are like, ‘what’s she really like?’ I’m like, 'She’s really like that, whatever you’re thinking.’ She’s perfect in every way. She’s better than the rest of us. She’s somehow superhuman.”
"I don't think I've ever read a text message from her that didn't make me laugh," she continues.
As for whether they'd ever reunite for "13 Going on 30" sequel?
"If someone wants to pay us to do that, I could imagine that we would do it. But there's nothing in the works," she says.

title: Behind the scenes at TODAY: Judy Greer gets starstruck, Jason Momoa’s proud dad moment and more
summary: Jason Momoa, Rachel Brosnahan, Judy Greer, Michelle Buteau and more stars came through the TODAY show this week. Here's what they told us behind the scenes.
story: In Greenroom Confidential, reporters and editors at TODAY.com share a look at what actors, authors, performers and more guests told us behind the scenes at TODAY. This first week of April, some of Hollywood’s biggest stars rolled through Studio 1A, from Kevin Bacon and Jenny Slate, to Danielle Brooks and Glen Powell. Take a peek!
Jason Momoa had a proud dad moment

After Jason Momoa spoke to Craig on the air Monday about his role in “A Minecraft Movie” — his first comedy role, if you can believe it — he chatted with TODAY.com a bit about parenting his two kids, Lola, 17, and Nakoa-Wolf, 16. His daughter is a singer, he said, while his son is pursuing acting.

“He really loves it,” Momoa added. “He just did a play last night. He was amazing in it. ... He had to do a monologue from ‘Ferris Bueller’s Day Off.’ It was a big, like, conglomerate of different kids doing different things, and he got to do ‘Ferris Bueller’s Day Off.’ He did great.”
How Michelle Buteau handles it all with ‘Survival of Thickest’

Also on Monday, Michelle Buteau stopped by Jenna & Friends to tell Jenna and guest co-host Olivia Munn about the second season of her Netflix series, “Survival of the Thickest.” She’s a co-creator, executive producer and star of the show and told us in the greenroom that it takes a “deep rooted sense of confidence” to be all three.

“Rejection is a part of it, and rejection is actually kind of fun — to know that it’s going to work out no matter what,” she said. “I think people get caught up in, ‘They said this and they don’t want this from me, and they canceled me.’ Yeah, that s--- is going to happen no matter what. ... It’s not supposed to be easy the whole time. That’s so boring. You get comedy from pain. So experience it, go through it, and then write about it.”
The lesson Hannah Einbinder learned from Jean Smart

“Hacks” is back for a fourth season on Max, and star Hannah Einbinder stopped by Tuesday to tell Jenna and Olivia Munn about what she and co-star Jean Smart have up their sleeves for their characters this time around. Einbinder and Smart are friends outside the show, and Einbinder told TODAY.com that she’s learned a lot from her co-star.

“Just as a person, she really shows up for people,” Einbinder said. “She’s really present, and she really, like, remembers birthdays and buys presents, and is, you know, attending what’s important to you, making sure that she’s there. She says yes to a lot. It’s huge.”
Judy Greer believes her pal Jennifer Garner is 'superhuman'
Walking out of the TODAY greenroom Wednesday, Judy Greer was “starstruck” during her run-in with “The Pitt” star Isa Briones, who happened to be there to support her friend.
“I was so excited. I hugged her!” she said. Greer raved about the HBO medical drama: “I I grew up watching Noah Wyle be a doctor, and I hope to die watching Noah Wyle be a doctor.”
Greer, who was here this week to promote her movie “Eric LaRue,” was also spotted filming Season 2 of “The Last Thing He Told Me,” alongside her friend and “13 Going on 30” co-star Jennifer Garner.

“Jen is exactly the kind of friend you would imagine. People are like, ‘What’s she really like? ‘I’m like, ‘She’s really like that. Whatever you’re thinking, she’s perfect in every way. She’s better than the rest of us. She’s somehow superhuman. I don’t think I’ve ever read a text message from her that didn’t make me laugh,” she said.
Glen Powell was once 'traumatized' by ketchup

Glen Powell stopped by TODAY Wednesday to discuss his new condiment line, and we learned about the time he was “traumatized” by ketchup in a sleepover mishap as a kid. He later held court in the TODAY greenroom, passing out samples from Smash Kitchen. At one point, he and Kristin Davis chatted about being on airplanes playing “Top Gun.”
On the show, he discussed bringing Sydney Sweeney to his sister’s wedding. He also gave more details about the celebration, including what he shared in his toast.
Kristin Davis shares her wisdom with the Home Edit ladies

Kristin Davis — on the show Wednesday to talk about her podcast, “Are You a Charlotte?” — taught Clea Shearer and Joanna Teplin of The Home Edit breathing techniques that help them adjust to the spotlight. It’s not the first time she’s helped people out.
“When people who are not performers are thrust into, you know, the public eye it’s hard, it’s really hard,” she said. “You forget to breathe.”
How Joanna Teplin and Clea Shearer get their kids to clean up
Joanna Teplin and Clea Shearer, the duo behind The Home Edit, a home organizing brand, on Wednesday let TODAY.com in on the tough love method they use to encourage their kids to clean up.
“The thing is, literally, if anything is out of place, I’m like, ‘Well, I’m going to donate it,’” Shearer said. “I assume you don’t like it.”

She said she “100%” follows through on her threats to donate. “I don’t even let them own enough things to get messy because I can’t have it in my house,” she said. “It makes me insane. So I’m going to donate it.”
Kevin Bacon has one place he goes to every week

After revealing to Savannah and Craig on Thursday that his new-found love of doing jigsaw puzzles helps shut off his brain for a while, Bacon chatted about his latest role as a demon hunter in the supernatural-action series “The Bondsman.”
Bacon later talked to TODAY.com about the upcoming Netflix series “Sirens,” in which he once again stars alongside Julianne Moore, his love interest in the film “Crazy, Stupid, Love.”
“She’s amazing,” he said of Moore. “I mean, she’s just one of the greats and an absolute joy to work with.”
Outside of working with the “great cast” of the new show, which also includes Meghann Fahy and Milly Alcock, Bacon said that making “Sirens” had another benefit.
“It was here in NYC and I could sleep in my own bed,” he says. “Which is not a requirement, but it is a bonus.”
His other favorite pastimes? Going to the movies.
"I go to them, I would say, once a week," he says. "I go to the theater, sit in the room, get the popcorn, go through that experience, because I love it."
Danielle Brooks shares what inspired her daughter's name
Danielle Brooks told TODAY.com on Thursday she can’t wait to bring her 5-year-old daughter, Freeya, to see the new “Minecraft” movie she stars in opposite Jack Black and Jason Momoa.

“As soon as I get home, I’m doing a private screening in Georgia. I get to take her. I cannot wait,” she said. “We’re going to watch this movie in a room full of family and friends. It’s going to be fun.”
Speaking of Freeya, Brooks also shared the inspiration behind her daughter’s name: She wants her to feel free, “plain and simple.”

“I want her to walk in this world and just know that whatever she wants to do, wherever she wants to be, she has the freedom to do so without judgment from her parents. I’m excited for to see who she becomes. We obviously still want to have structure in her life, but the freedom to be the human that she wants to be is important,” she said.
How Jenny Slate connected to the real-life person who inspired her new role
Jenny Slate is only choosing projects that let her go “full wingspan,” she told The Hollywood Reporter. What does that mean, exactly?
“It means to me that I’m really touched by the material,” she told TODAY.com on Thursday. “I want to do projects that reflect how much I believe in myself.”

Slate stars opposite Michelle Williams in the FX series “Dying for Sex,” which premieres April 4. In the series, which is based on a true story, Williams plays Molly, a woman who embarks on a sexual awakening after being diagnosed with cancer. Slate is her best friend, Nikki. (As for the real-life inspirations: Nikki Boyer is an executive producer on the show; Molly Kochan died of breast cancer in 2019.)
Slate remembered a day that stood out from set when she felt a connection to Kochan. At the time, Slate and Williams were waiting in an apartment in Brooklyn to film a scene.

“I was thinking about Molly and feeling just really intense emotions. And I looked out the window and there was this absolutely beautiful apple blossom tree. I felt so strongly a connection to Molly in that moment. That beautiful blooming. And I remember thinking like, I will really, really try to do my best by you,” she said.
What Rachel Brosnahan will bring to Lois Lane

Rachel Brosnahan has a new spy thriller movie called “The Amateur,” in which she stars alongside Rami Malek, and dropped by Studio 1A on Friday to share all about it. It was perfect timing, too, as a trailer for “Superman,” in which Brosnahan steps into the iconic character of Lois Lane, had also dropped the day before.
So how did she prepare to step into Lois’ shoes?

“She’s one of the characters that’s evolved the most in the history of these comics,” she told TODAY.com. “She always represents whatever the modern intrepid journalist who is hungry and courageous and determined feels like, and that’s looked like a lot of different things over time. So (writer-director) James (Gunn) laid the roadmap for us with his brilliant script. We had a lot of conversation about how he saw this character fitting into the canon of previous ‘Superman’ iterations, and then, and then just spend a lot of time trying on things for size.”
What Dichen Lachman thinks about those goats in ‘Severence’

“Mum” was totally the word when “Severance” actor Dichen Lachman spoke on TODAY about spoilers for the Season 2 finale. The cliffhanger left fans pondering the fate of Lachman’s character, Gemma Scout, otherwise known as Ms. Casey.
While Lachman couldn’t say what’s to come when the series returns, she did talk to TODAY.com about the show’s other compelling topic: those goats!
“I do believe that the others had an opportunity to work with the goats,” Lachman said. “I, sadly, only got to sort of wave to them from afar. But they’re so cute.”
Perhaps it was for the best, because according to the Australian actor, working with goats can sometimes be a real challenge.
“I did, once, in a very old movie, get head-butted by a goat. That wasn’t on film, but I have worked with goats before and they can be quite diva-ish,” she laughed.

title: EXCLUSIVE: Get an exclusive peek at tonight's ‘Grosse Pointe Garden Society’
summary: Is Catherine’s “guilty” secret about to be exposed? Watch an exclusive TODAY.com clip of the next episode of "Grosse Pointe Garden Society," out April 4.
story: Is Catherine’s “guilty” secret about to be exposed on tonight's episode of "Grosse Pointe Garden Society"?
Since NBC’s new drama series “Grosse Pointe Garden Society” premiered in February, fans have been waiting for more clues about who the four main characters secretly murdered.

In case you haven’t tuned in yet, “Grosse Pointe Garden Society” tells the story of four suburban friends — Birdie (Melissa Fumero), Catherine (Aja Naomi King), Brett (Ben Rappaport) and Alice (AnnaSophia Robb) — in Michigan who are members of a garden club.
The first episode ended with a cliffhanger that revealed six months in the future Birdie, Catherine, Brett and Alice will work together to hide a dead body and cover up a murder.

The show has yet to reveal the identity of the deceased, but each episode viewers learn more about that murderous night and who is still alive in the future. We also see how events six months prior caused each of the four main garden club members to have a motive and be vengeful enough to commit a deadly crime.

In a TODAY.com exclusive clip from Episode 7, titled “Germination,” Catherine is confronted by her husband, Tucker (Jocko Sims), shortly after she returns home from burying the mystery character with her friends.

Six months in the future, Catherine is shown sneaking into her house during the wee hours of the morning, looking distraught and disheveled. Suddenly thirsty, she gulps down some orange juice before realizing her husband has been watching her. Tucker then questions where she has been all night.

A press release for the new episode, out April 4, teases that “Catherine’s marriage faces new hurdles when law enforcement seeks answers” about her whereabouts that night. Elsewhere, “Alice faces unexpected challenges at work. Brett feels pressure launching his car restoration business. Birdie grows more involved in a tempting affair.”
Watch the clip below and tune into “Grosse Pointe Garden Society” — now airing on Fridays at 8 p.m. ET — to see if you can figure out which character was killed.

title: Which ‘Sex and the City’ character are you, really? Kristin Davis’ guide to figuring it out
summary: Are you a Carrie, Samantha, Miranda or Charlotte? Kristin Davis tells us her guide to figuring out which Sex and the City character you are.
story: Are you a Carrie, Charlotte, Miranda or a Samantha?
It's a question as old as time (or at least since June 6, 1998, when "Sex and the City" premiered on HBO).

The show's four leading ladies collectively comprise a group of best friends in their 30s, navigating life and relationships in New York City in a time after the "end of love in Manhattan," as Carrie (Sarah Jessica Parker) puts it in the pilot.

Their friendship is maintained through phone calls, parties, cab rides and meals and often consists of a central debate, with each person bringing a different perspective to the situation. Their conversations are full of banter and little disagreements, with each scene illuminating just how different each character is, setting up a perfect — and lasting — form of self-categorization.
Kristin Davis, who plays Charlotte, says she fittingly identifies as a "Charlotte."
"I think BuzzFeed had a quiz and people send it around. My daughter has gotten it, which is hysterical, and luckily she is a Charlotte," she tells TODAY.com with a laugh, referring to daughter Gemma.
The personality litmus test also lent itself to her latest venture, a "Sex and the City" rewatch podcast called, "Are You A Charlotte?" The goal of the podcast is to connect with fans, she says.

Currently on the podcast, Davis and her guests — a lineup she says will include TODAY's own Jenna Bush Hager, "Sex and the City" author Candace Bushnell and Sarah Jessica Parker — are still rewatching Season 1.

"The first season, especially, I barely remember it," Davis says. "Because we used to film really quickly, also, so we would film all night. Maybe we had five days, I want to say, an episode ... I'd have to go back, it might have even been four. Like it was fast."
Now, there's more time dedicated to filming each episode, she says. Davis currently stars as Charlotte in "And Just Like That...," the "Sex and the City" revival.

Headed into Season 3, Davis calls it "a big season." Viewers left Charlotte in Season 2 on her journey of returning to work while balancing the expectations of being a wife and mother, including setting husband Harry (Evan Handler) straight on the division of their workload.

"The pressure of trying to be a good wife, be a good mother, her children are getting older, so she's trying to figure out, 'How much time can I devote to my career, at my job? ... What do I need to succeed?'" Davis says. "This is a big question for everyone, so I really relate to it myself, obviously, too. And that continues through the season, and you're going to see her really struggle with that.
"And it's a fun, fun storyline," she adds.

"And Just Like That...," which premiered in December 2021, reunited Davis, Nixon and Parker as Charlotte, Miranda and Carrie. Season 2 memorably saw the brief return of Samantha, when Kim Cattrall made a cameo in the finale.
How to tell if you're a Carrie, Charlotte, Samantha or Miranda

While fans have been categorizing themselves as a Carrie, Charlotte, Miranda or Samantha for years, Davis has her own ideas for how to decide which character you're most like. She boils it down to four key questions to ask yourself, centered on each character's core identity:
Are you a searcher? Are you a trailblazer?Do you say it like it is?Are you looking for a traditional outcome for your life?
Are you a searcher?
Are you a trailblazer?
Do you say it like it is?
Are you looking for a traditional outcome for your life?
After whichever question has you shouting, "Yes!" the most definitively, read on for which "Sex and the City" character that makes you.
Are you a searcher?
Yes? Congrats, you're a ...
Carrie!
"In terms of the other (characters), like Carrie, I would say, are you a searcher? Are you looking for answers? Are you investigating things?" Davis poses.

In each episode of the original show, Parker’s character, a columnist, took on a relationship or life dilemma, and in the process of writing it, often framed the issue as a question. Davis says the key to Carrie's identity is her signature phrase: "I couldn't help but wonder."
Carrie is also "not so worried about tradition," Davis notes.
"Carrie is more independent and looking for what would make her happy, not necessarily what society might be expecting," she says.
Are you a trailblazer?
Then you're a...
Samantha!
Taking things a step further from Carrie's independence, Davis describes Samantha as a "trailblazer."
"Are you super independent?" Davis says. "Are you unapologetic about getting what you need? Such good qualities, powerful qualities."
Do you say it like it is?
You're most like...
Miranda!
Davis describes a Miranda as someone "open in how you talk."
"Do you say it like it is?" she says. "Are you open to eating food out of a trash can? Do you like cats?"
A huge part of a Miranda's identity is also career-centric, she says.
"Are you into your career? She is a lawyer, and she's very good at it, and she wants to become partner, and she's super smart," Davis says. "So are you super smart? That would be a Miranda question."
Are you looking for a traditional outcome for your life?
If yes, you are a...
Charlotte!
“First of all, in terms of, are you a Charlotte, I would say, ‘Do you believe in love? Are you loyal?’” Davis adds.
At her core, Charlotte is looking for “a traditional outcome” to her life. She also has certain material loves that are part of her identity, too, Davis says.
“Do you love dogs? Are you into structured and starched clothing?” Davis asks with a laugh. “Do you like white flowers?”

title: Teddi Mellencamp’s husband tried not to ‘sugarcoat’ news of her cancer when talking to their kids
summary: Edwin Arroyave, Teddi Mellencamp’s husband, says he was honest with their kids when he shared updates about her melanoma cancer diagnosis, which is now Stage 4.
story: Edwin Arroyave says he was honest with his kids when he shared updates about Teddi Mellencamp’s cancer journey.
“I was upfront with them with what was going on. I didn’t sugarcoat it,” he said on the April 3 episode of the podcast he co-hosts with Eddie Judge, “The Eds.”
Mellencamp, 43, recently revealed she has been diagnosed with four more brain tumors, and that her cancer, melanoma, is now Stage 4.
It’s unclear whether Arroyave’s podcast episode was recorded before or after this latest development in her prognosis.
“They got scared, obviously, they were concerned,” Arroyave, 47, said of the three children he shares with Mellencamp: Slate, 12, Cruz, 10, and Dove, 5.

“But I tried my best to, again, not sugarcoat it too much,” he continued. “(I) let them know, ‘Hey, there are some risks that come with this.’ You know, I called it the way it was. It’s like, ‘Hey, there’s some tumors that your mom has in her brain.’”

“And I said, ‘It sounds worse than what it is. But this is what I think is, this is what we think is going to happen,’” he added. “‘This is sort of how we’re going to deal with it, and this is why I’m confident that she’s going to make it through.’”
In February, Mellencamp underwent surgery after multiple brain tumors were discovered via a CT scan and MRI. The following month, she revealed she had two additional tumors in her lungs.
The former “Real Housewives of Beverly Hills” star’s cancer journey began in 2022 when she had a suspicious discolored spot removed. It turned out to be melanoma, a type of skin cancer.
Melanoma is rarer than other types of skin cancers, and it can also be more deadly because of its likelihood to spread if not treated early, according to the American Cancer society.
The tumors in Mellencamp’s brain and lungs were the result of her melanoma metastasizing, or spreading to other parts of her body.
“I’m fighting for my life,” Mellencamp told Us Weekly as she revealed her Stage 4 diagnosis. “But also for my family’s life and all the people I love.”

“You know, I’ve got to tell you, some days I feel really, really strong and some days I feel really, really sad and alone, and I think that’s a normal part of what any of us are going through and that’s OK,” she said in her Instagram story on April 2. “Stage 4 cancer can be scary.”
Arroyave and Mellencamp are separated, but continue to support each other and their kids. In fact, they still live in the same house, an arrangement Mellencamp says works great for them.
“I’m in the primary (bedroom), and he’s in one of the guest rooms. It’s fun,” she told Us Weekly. “It’s all the things that I loved about our marriage, but without all the problems.”
She added that Arroyave has been there for her “a hundred percent” throughout her illness.

“He’s been there for the kids, and we’re back to laughing,” she said. “We call it the ‘Divorce Chronicles.’ And I want to talk (to him) about the kind of girls (he’s) going to marry … because if these people are going to take care of my kids, this is what I want, and this is the definition of what I don’t want.”

title: Raven-Symoné clarifies past comments about her race — and fans say they 'completely' agree
summary: In a new interview, Raven-Symoné clarified the past remarks she made to Oprah Winfrey when she said she doesn't consider herself an African American.
story: Raven-Symoné is getting candid about her identity.

During an appearance on "The Jason Lee Show," Raven-Symoné talked about the past comments she made to Oprah Winfrey in 2014 when she told her that she doesn't identify as an African American. Instead, Raven-Symoné said she's simply “an American."

At the time, the "That's So Raven" star received quite a bit of backlash online for her comments about her race. Now, in her interview with Lee, she is once again addressing it and clarifying what she meant.
"I am not an African American. I'm an American. I am a Black American. I am definitely Black. And yes, my ancestors come from Africa," she said.

"How long does a bloodline have to live in one land before they are considered a pure species of that land? Meaning, how long did my people have to be in America to say, 'Hey, no, we're American," compared to some people who are English American, who are Irish American, who are German American from their ancestors, but they get to call themselves American," Raven-Symoné continued.

The "Cheetah Girls" singer explained that there is "nothing wrong" with someone identifying as African American, "but a true African American is someone that is from Africa and moved here, either first generation or second generation, and has a tie to that country that I do not have."
She also noted that her family has been in America for quite some time and were part of the "first census in Virginia that allowed for Black people to have a name."

"I think there comes a point where, when you build a country, when you fight for freedom, make money and pay taxes and generationally live in a country, you have the privilege to call yourself pure American," she added.
On Instagram, people said they agreed with Raven-Symoné and they loved they way she explained herself.
"You know what...I, too must eat my words because that really rubbed me the wrong way when she said it back then but hearing the ENTIRE perspective made me agree with her," one person commented.
Another said, "Didn’t agree with her back then, COMPLETELY AGREE with her now. She was ahead of her time!"
A third added, "She’s right, once your 4+ generations deep in America you do have more ties to America vs Africa, but I do remember looking sideways when she first made that statement 👀😅."
Meanwhile a fourth commented, "Africans call us Black American. They themselves don’t even consider us African any longer either lol. Just Black American lol."
In April 2024, Raven-Symoné also spoke about those comments she made to Winfrey on her and her wife's podcast, “Tea Time With Raven & Miranda."

There, Raven-Symoné said that she immediately felt "judged" when she saw all the backlash that she was getting from the public back then. She also said her mom thought that Winfrey had set her up for that response because the mogul had reacted to her comments right away, instead of letting her finish her thoughts in the interview.
The "Dr. Dolittle 2" star said that she felt like she had “said something that’s bad" when she walked off stage, "which contradicts who I am as a human.”
Though she doesn't think that Winfrey set her up, she did say she thought that Winfrey shined a light on her remarks so that people could "scrutinize more.”

Not to mention, Raven-Symoné, who also identifies as a "human who loves humans," said that interview was supposed to be her coming out interview, but it instead became a conversation about labels, even though she said she was “tired of being labeled.”
“I said, ‘Don’t label me’ and it turned into that instead of my coming out,” she said.

title: Does Kevin Bacon relate to his demon-hunting character in ‘Bondsman’? Surprisingly, yes
summary: Kevin Bacon plays a demon hunter from hell in "The Bondsman, and he reveals the surprising thing he shares in common with his TV counterpart.
story: Kevin Bacon has played almost every kind of character imaginable over the course of his tenured career, but it's his latest role in the new series, "The Bondsman," that has the 66-year-old actor catching hell as Hub Halloran, a demon-hunter searching for redemption.

"It was a fun show for me because there's a lot of physical challenges, which I really like. There's a lot of running, jumping, fighting and underwater stuff," Bacon says during a sit-down interview with TODAY.com
"You know, just basically demon ass-kicking," he laughs.

The new Prime series, which premiered on April 3, is about a murdered bounty hunter (Bacon) resurrected by Satan to help track down escaped demons, so it's naturally going to be hellish. But fortunately, for Bacon, it’s in all the right ways.

"What's really fun to me is the fact that the character is such a badass, but at the same time, he's such a child in a lot of ways," Bacon says of the role. "He's living in his mother's garage, he hasn't been able to make it work with his ex-wife. He's estranged from his son. He's kind of a mess in his life."
That complicated backstory is exactly why he enjoyed taking on the character. "If you're going to play somebody who is ultimately the hero of the show, it's fun to have that kind of complexity."

Produced by showrunner Erik Oleson, "The Bondsman" also stars Beth Grant as Kitty Halloran, Bacon's tough-as-nails mother, Maxwell Jenkins as his son, Cade, and Sugarland's Jennifer Nettles as the ex-wife he still carries a torch for.
It's a campy, often gory mix of comedy, action and straight-up horror as Bacon battles various demons as part of a mission he's been sent on to round up wayward demons by the Devil himself.
No stranger to the genre, the "Footloose" actor has appeared in a variety of horror films, including the original "Friday the 13th," "Hollow Man" and "Tremors."
Beyond it's genre identity, "The Bondsman" is also a metaphor for personal redemption, with its phrase, "to hell and back," serving as both a literal and figurative meaning.
Kevin Bacon vs. Hub Halloran: Similar or different?
While Bacon says he doesn't connect with his character Hub's alter ego, they do share a passion for music.

Along with acting, Bacon has spent decades touring with his brother, Michael, as one half of the musical duo known as The Bacon Brothers. Hub, a failed musician, provided Bacon with the perfect opportunity to marry two of his loves in "The Bondsman."

"It came up when we were about to pitch ("The Bondsman"), that it might be fun for me to write some songs, and then Jennifer (Nettles) got cast, and she was definitely the best person for the part, the best actress, but she was also a fabulous singer and a great, great songwriter," Bacon tells Craig Melvin and Savannah Guthrie during a segment on TODAY April 3.
"So, right away, we wrote a song, and that song was rejected,” Bacon said. "And then we wrote some more, and wrote some more, and we ended up with three of our tunes in the show."
Music, however, isn't the only thing that Bacon and Hub have in common. Bacon says that Hub's calm and collected way of dealing with chaos is something he can relate to.

"Part of the humor lies in the fact that when all this crazy stuff starts happening around (Hub), he's pretty cool around it. He's like, 'OK, well, now, I've come back from the dead and now I've got to go and hunt these demons. So, let me just figure out how I'm going to do that.' You know what I mean? I would say, if anything, that's a similar quality," explains Bacon.
Big screen vs. little screen: Which does Kevin Bacon prefer?

"The Bondsman" is far from Bacon's first TV series. The actor also starred in the 2019 cop drama "City on a Hill," the 2016 comedy  "I Love Dick" and the 2013 serial killer series "The Following," among others.
He also stars opposite Julianne Moore in the upcoming Netflix series, "Sirens," which will be released on May 22.
Having appeared on both the big and little screens, does Bacon have a preference between the two?

"When I started out, all I wanted was to be in movies and on the stage. Those were my two dreams," he explains. "It's hard to imagine, but back then, if you went from the movies to the small screen, it was kind of a sign that you were throwing in the towel.

"Now, movie stars left and right do it, everyone does it, and I love it. I'd never not do TV," Bacon continues. "I also really love movies and I go to them, I would say, maybe once a week. I go to the theater, sit in the room, get the popcorn, go through that experience because I love it."

title: Mexican officials deny Fyre Festival 2 is happening in Playa del Carmen
summary: Officials in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, deny Fyre Festival 2 will take place, despite festival organizer Billy McFarland previously saying it will.
story: It looks like the second time may not be the charm for Fyre Festival.
The location that was said to be the site of next month’s Fyre Festival 2 may not serve as the venue, leading to questions about where the event will be held.

Fyre Festival founder Billy McFarland, who announced last September plans for a sequel for the festival, said last week at a press conference that the new event would take place in Playa del Carmen, Mexico.
In an April 3 post on X, however, city hall in Playa del Carmen said on X that it will not play host for the festival.
“... No such event with that name will take place in our city,” it wrote.
“There is no existence of a registry nor plans that would indicate such an event taking place in this municipality,” it added.
The comments came after McFarland spoke glowingly of the area during a recent press conference.
“Our relationships with Playa may be new, but I know I speak for the rest of the team when I say we couldn’t ask for a better group of people,” he said.

“We are very happy to have this festival in Mexico, in Playa del Carmen. We already have permits, so this is going to be very successful,” entrepreneur and Playa del Carmen’s Martina Beach Club founder Fernando Delgado said at the press conference.

This confusion over where Fyre Festival 2 — which has not announced any artists who will be performing — follows the disastrous first Fyre Festival in 2017. The location was moved four months before the start date, and while customers were initially promised a luxury experience, they were served cheese sandwiches and put up in emergency relief tents instead.

McFarland wound up serving four years in prison for fraud for that event. Still, he has remained committed to putting on another Fyre Festival, with tickets ranging in price from $1,400 to more than $1 million.
“I think Fyre 2 really isn’t about the past, and it’s not really about me. It’s about taking the vision, which is strong,” he told TODAY in an interview that aired in February.
McFarland also knows people may be taking a chance in buying a ticket.
“I think it’s always a risk,” he said. “You’re taking a risk because I made a lot of bad decisions and messed up the first festival. Until it’s experienced, there is a risk component to it.”

title: Jack Black surprises Tanner from 'Love On The Spectrum' in heartwarming moment
summary: "Love on the Spectrum" star Tanner Smith received a surprise from his favorite actor Jack Black during a heartwarming moment on "The Kelly Clarkson Show."
story: There’s joy, and then there is Tanner Smith-level joy.

The star of Netflix’s “Love on the Spectrum” recently appeared on “The Kelly Clarkson Show,” where his trademark enthusiasm skyrocketed to new heights when he received a surprise from his lifelong idol.

During the talk show, Smith sat down with host Kelly Clarkson to talk about the series’ third season, which is currently available to stream on the platform. After discussing his recent dates on the reality series, Clarkson reminded Smith of his previous appearance on her show, during which he received a special video message from Jack Black.
Building on this memory, Clarkson discussed Smith’s ongoing dream to meet Black in person.
“I want to be 31 when I meet him,” Smith said.
“We asked Jack if he could make another video for you,” Clarkson added.
Black then appeared on the screen with a big smile and greeted Smith.

“What’s up, Tanner? Jack Black, here,” the actor said in the clip. “I still cannot wait to meet you in person, but I’m on the road with ‘A Minecraft Movie’ right now. But luckily, I have insane ninja, kung fu powers, which means I can come through these doors and I’m gonna see you right now when I come through these doors! Tanner, I’m here right now!”
Black then burst through the doors and ran towards the stage. Smith sprang onto his feet, rushed towards the actor and gave him a big embrace.

“Jack, it’s you! Jack, I’m so excited to meet you! Jack! Jack! I’m so glad I finally get to meet you!” Smith, filled with enthusiasm, said at lightning speed to Black as they interacted face-to-face for the first time. “Jack, I’m so happy to meet you! Jack, I’m your biggest fan ‘cause you’re a great actor and a great singer. So I’m happy to finally meet you!”
Later, seated on the couch, Smith continued to enthusiastically shower Black with praise.
“You’re so handsome. You’re looking good, Jack,” Smith continued. “And Jack, you’re a great actor, just like me, and you’re very strong too.”
“I am? You know what, I do work out a little bit now,” Black replied. “We should do some weightlifting together. You could teach me some tips.”
“Yes, sir!” Smith quickly responded. “Guess what, I’m gonna get your phone number and we can work out together!”
The honest response made Black burst into laughter. “This is happening!” he replied.

As Smith’s excitement continued, Black remarked, “I gotta take off my glasses. My glasses are steaming up,” before turning to Smith warmly. “Hey, I love you on the show, and I can’t wait for the next season. I’m so happy for you having all of this success and (wonderful) time in your life. And to meet you in person is really amazing for me too.”
“Yeah, Jack,” Smith replied. “It’s really amazing for me too.”
Smith then turned to Clarkson with a beaming smile.
“Thank you so much, Miss Kelly. Miss Kelly, thank you so much!” he said. “This is the best day of my life.”

title: Tom Cruise pays tribute to Val Kilmer with a moment of silence at CinemaCon
summary: Tom Cruise led his appearance at CinemaCon with words about the late Val Kilmer.
story: Tom Cruise is paying his respects to his former co-star and “dear friend” Val Kilmer.

The actor made an appearance at CinemaCon on April 3 in Las Vegas to promote “Mission: Impossible — The Final Reckoning.” But before he impressed the audience with a sneak peek of the upcoming action film, Cruise asked for a moment of silence for the late actor who died on April 1.

“I’d like to honor a dear friend of mine, Val Kilmer,” Cruise, 62, said, according to E! News. “I can’t tell you how much I admire his work, how grateful and honored I was when he joined ‘Top Gun’ and came back later for ‘Top Gun: Maverick.’”
Kilmer portrayed Lt. Tom “Iceman” Kazanski in the 1986 “Top Gun” film starring Cruise as Pete "Maverick" Mitchell. The two were rival fighter pilots who eventually became friends.
The film catapulted both Kilmer and Cruise's careers, leading to a slew of box office hits for the two movie stars.
When the sequel, “Top Gun: Maverick” was released in 2022, Kilmer made a brief cameo as Iceman. The role would be his final acting credit.
During CinemaCon, Cruise took a moment to reflect on Kilmer's friendship and success.

“I think it would be really nice if we could have a moment together because he loved movies and he gave a lot to all of us,” he said. “Just kind of think about all the wonderful times that we had with him.”
E! News reported that Cruise praised Kilmer for his knack for storytelling and compared him to producer Irving Thalberg, a pioneer in the early years of cinema.
“This man forged through it all and was able to create epic adventures for global audiences,” Cruise said. “You are an artist for all time. You are our modern-day Thalberg.”
In a 2022 interview with Collider, Kilmer said it was a “pleasure” to have been able to reprise his role as Iceman and work with Cruise.
“We are paid to act and that’s what we did in the scene,” Kilmer said. “But doing so with a class act like Tom made it a pleasure, and less like work!”
Kilmer died at the age of 65 from pneumonia, his daughter, Mercedes Kilmer, told the Associated Press.

“The Doors” star had previously been diagnosed with throat cancer in 2015. While he had kept his diagnosis private at that time, he later shared it with the world in a 2021 documentary titled “Val” that chronicled his health issues.

Kilmer underwent a tracheostomy, which affected his ability to talk,  and used a voice box to speak. In his “Top Gun: Maverick” scene, Iceman is also battling cancer when Maverick pays him a visit and asks for his advice on sending a crew member on a potential fatal mission. Iceman is seen typing, “It’s time to let go,” and Maverick emotionally says, “I don’t know how.”
He also has a speaking line, which, according to his daughter, was dubbed with the use of software company Sonantic, which re-created his voice.
While Kilmer shared that he was cancer-free in 2021, his family did not share if his pneumonia was related to his throat cancer battle.

title: 'Boy Meets World' stars reflect on a Season 6 episode that was 'painful' to watch
summary: “Boy Meets World” stars have mixed feelings about a complicated storyline from Season 6 of the show, guest starring Fred Savage as an inappropriate college professor.
story: “Boy Meets World” stars have mixed feelings today about a complicated storyline that Will Friedle described as having an “important message, not great execution.”

In the latest “Pod Meets World” episode, podcast hosts Friedle, Danielle Fishel and Rider Strong criticized a 1998 episode titled “Everybody Loves Stuart,” in which a college professor makes an inappropriate move on Fishel’s character Topanga.
The theme of the episode, in their opinion, is, “What happens when people in position of power take advantage of your trust.” The trio, however, were frustrated with the way the storyline plays out.

Professor Stuart is portrayed by Fred Savage, the older brother of “Boy Meet World” star Ben Savage. In it, he is known as the “cool teacher” and makes a pass on Topanga, who is one of his students and is engaged to Ben Savage’s Cory.
“I didn’t like (it),” Friedle said. “Topanga just sits there, quiet through the whole freaking thing, like, never speaks. It’s not about her at all.”

In the episode, Cory becomes furious after Topanga tells him that Stuart hit on her in her dorm room. Cory confronts the professor and pushes him into a screen window in the common room. Because of his actions, he is at risk of being expelled.
The “Pod Meets World” hosts disliked how the storyline turned its focus on Cory instead of Topanga, who was the actual victim.

Fishel agreed with Friedle, saying that being harassed by her professor became less about Topanga and more about, “How is the man in her life going to feel about it, and what’s he going to do about it?”
“Topanga's agency was completely just taken away, I did not appreciate that at all,” she said.

“How do we get across how important this is without being too heavy handed, and without trying to seem like we’re making light of it?" she added. “I don’t think that goal was achieved. I do think they just decided, let’s lean into the melodrama of it.”
Friedle went on to note that the “one time Topanga opens her mouth, she’s told to be quiet by the dean.”
“She never tells her story to anybody that can help,” he continued, adding that Cory doesn’t even share Topanga’s story. Instead, it's Mr. Feeny who takes charge.
Strong, who called the episode “painful” to watch, wondered why it was Cory’s responsibility to stand up for Topanga.
“Why is it Cory’s responsibility to take the fall when he does stand up for her?” he asked.
“The concern is not how Topanga feels,” Strong added. “It’s about how the violation of Topanga is reflected through how it violates Cory’s rights ... It just made me so uncomfortable.”

Fishel did point out that the show is titled “Boy Meets World,” which centers on Cory’s point of view. However, she believed the episode could have benefited from a scene where Cory asks Topanga, “What do you want to do about this? This happened to you... How can I best support you?”
Fishel said she was also confused by Cory pushing Stuart and how it’s unknown if Topanga asks Cory to confront him.
“We don’t even know whether or not Topanga wants this to happen or is expecting him to say something,” she said, adding that what happens to her character “becomes unimportant.”
As the trio continued to watch the episode, Friedle said, overall, he was “so thrown by this episode.”

“The second Cory walks in, it is now Cory’s taking over the story and it’s about how he’s going to deal with what happened to Topanga," Friedle said. “They should’ve stayed with the Topanga storyline."

title: Patrick Schwarzenegger's mom, Maria Shriver, reveals the 1 way he's like his 'White Lotus' character
summary: Maria Shriver, while promoting her poetry book, "I Am Maria," talks to TODAY.com about son Patrick Schwarzenegger's shared habit with his "White Lotus" character.
story: Warning: This post contains spoilers for Season Three of "The White Lotus."
Maria Shriver contends her son Patrick Schwarzenegger is nothing like his character Saxon Ratliff on Season Three of "The White Lotus" — except for one of his habits.
Shriver tells TODAY.com that Schwarzenegger is guilty of turning on a blender at odd hours of the day.
"The only thing Patrick does do like Saxon is push the button on the Vitamix," she says, adding her younger son, Christopher Schwarzenegger, also has the bad habit.
"Both my boys are like, you know, it's quiet in the morning and then, 'Boom!' That blender goes off, and I'm like, 'Really? Really?'" Shriver recalls through laughter.

"He and his brother, both, are like, 'Zzt,' and early," she says, mimicking the sound of a blender. "It's the worst. I'm just, like, 'Excuse me?' And they're like, 'What? It's just the blender.' I'm like, why doesn't somebody make a quiet blender? I don't know why they don't do that."

Shriver, who is promoting her new poetry book, "I Am Maria," jokes that she should have titled the collection "I Am Patrick's Mom," due to all the attention her son has been getting for his role on "The White Lotus."
"Everybody wants to know what it's like to be Patrick, or is Patrick like Saxon? No, he's not. Is Patrick really a wonderful person? Yes, he is," she says. "What did I think of his bare butt?"
During Shriver's TODAY appearance April 1, the day her poetry book was published, co-anchor Craig Melvin asked if she has to get up and leave the room while watching some of the scenes.
"Well, I've seen his butt before, so," she said with a grin. "It's just gotten bigger."
She tells TODAY.com the amount of questions has been overwhelming, but that she's proud of her son.

"I'm happy for him because he's worked so hard. He takes acting classes all the time, and for every role like this you get, you're rejected like 300 times. You have to be resilient. You have to stay at it. And he has really stayed at it. And he'll have to stay at it after this. He's got to have life after 'White Lotus,' but his life during 'White Lotus' is pretty wild."

In this season of the hit HBO show, Schwarzenegger portrays an entitled finance bro who works for his father's business in North Carolina. The Ratliff family is vacationing in Thailand to help Saxon's sister, Piper (Sarah Catherine Hook), complete her college thesis — or so she says.

About halfway through the season, Piper reveals she actually wanted to travel to the country to visit a monastery to meet a monk she wants to study under for a year, all while her dad, Tim (Jason Isaacs), learns there is a warrant out for his arrest back in the U.S.
The fate of the Ratliffs will be revealed during the finale April 6, and Shriver says she believed she would be able to watch the last episode with her son.

"I thought I was watching it with Patrick and all his friends, and I changed my book tour to be home, and then he announced to me the other day that they're doing a 'White Lotus' working thing that I'm not invited to," she says. "I said, 'Well, then I just guess I'll do my own finale party with your friends, without you.'"
Shriver says her son told her he would love to be there with her and that he was sorry, but she's still worried for his character in the finale.
"I'm really hoping he doesn't get killed," Shriver says.

title: See Robert Irwin like you never have before in new underwear campaign
summary: Robert Irwin stars in a new underwear campaign for the Australian brand Bonds.
story: Robert Irwin is showing off a more daring side of himself as the star of a new photo campaign for the Australian underwear brand Bonds.

Irwin, the 21-year-old son of late “Crocodile Hunter” Steve Irwin, posed for several images in Bonds' cheeky new "Made for Down Under" campaign wearing nothing but his skivvies while joined by a few wild animals.

Bonds, which is currently launching in the United States, shared a video of Robert Irwin on Instagram that showed the young conservationist sitting in a lawn chair with a snake wrapped around his arm and shoulder.
As a tarantula crawls up Irwin’s leg, a crocodile stares at him from nearby in the grass.
Irwin, who inherited his father’s love of wildlife, told People he jumped at the chance to appear in the campaign.

“I mean, I’ve spent my life wrangling crocs and snakes and rescuing animals. And so to feature a little slice of that excitement in this new campaign, mate, it has been so much fun,” he said. “I mean, I’m surrounded by spiders and snakes except (this time) I’m in my undies. That’s the only difference.”
Irwin said he wanted to look his best for the photos since he's "representing Australia." That required “more sit-ups” and “less carbs," he said.
Irwin added that staying in shape, for him, isn't too difficult thanks to the demands of his everyday life at his family's Australian Zoo.

“I’ve got to stay pretty fit with all the crazy stuff I’m doing,” he said. ‘I’m saving crocodiles, I’m in and out of the Aussie bush every day and it’s hard work, so you’ve got to keep pretty good upper body strength, good stamina.”
He added, “At Australia Zoo, our beautiful wildlife sanctuary, it’s great, I’ve got about 700 acres to just run. So I’ve been doing a lot of sprints, a lot of hill sprints.”
Irwin made his modeling debut in March 2024 when he walked the runway at the Melbourne Fashion Festival.
“Never imagined I’d be walking the runway, but here we are,” Irwin captioned a collection of photos from the event on Instagram. “Wow, thanks for an amazing night Melbourne Fashion Festival!!”

title: Danielle Brooks shares the hidden meaning of her ‘Minecraft’ costume
summary: Danielle Brooks told TODAY her Minecraft costume, which is orange and purple, has a hidden meaning.
story: Danielle Brooks revealed that the jumpsuit she sports in the upcoming “A Minecraft Movie” has a hidden meaning.
The Oscar-nominated actor recently spoke with TODAY.com about starring in the adventure comedy, which hits theaters April 4, and shared some secret behind-the-scenes details from filming.

While the family-friendly film is more light-hearted compared to her dramatic roles in movies like “The Color Purple” and shows like “Orange Is the New Black,” Brooks still managed to pay homage to the beloved characters from those past projects.

In “A Minecraft Movie” Brooks portrays Dawn, one of four misfits who are pulled through a portal and land in the Overworld. Her character dons a bright orange and purple in the film, a nod to “The Color Purple” and “OITNB.”
“What was cool is our costume designer, Amanda (Neale), she, I think, was very intentional about having orange and purple in my outfit,” Brooks told TODAY.com. “So I thought that was pretty cool.”

She said she instantly understood why Neale chose the two colors for Dawn. “I was like, ‘You realize this is, like, the height of my career? These two colors, orange and purple? She was like, ‘Yes, I know.’ I loved it.”
Brooks shared that co-star Jason Momoa was also a big fan of the colorful costume.
“Jason loved it even more,” she added. “He had (Neale) make him one of my jumpsuits.”
She said Momoa had planned to wear the orange and purple jumpsuit at one of the film’s premieres, but it didn’t arrive in time.

Brooks also had a suggestion for their characters’ styling in a possible sequel. “If we get a sequel, I think we should really think of some fun, funky hair,” she said, noting Momoa’s luscious locks in the fantasy flick and the recent mullet he showed off during an appearance on TODAY.

In addition to Brooks and Momoa, “A Minecraft Movie” also stars Jack Black, Jennifer Coolidge and Emma Myers. Brooks said she that is looking forward to fans seeing the movie, which is based on the “Minecraft” video game.

“I’m just really excited for people to watch it, and I hope that it reminds you to dance a little bit longer,” she shared. “And, maybe, you know, pop the champagne after you’ve shaken it up a little bit. I just want people to live as free as they possibly can.”
One important person she can’t wait to see the movie is her 5-year-old daughter, Freeya, whom she shares with husband Dennis Gelin.

Brooks said, “I’m going to take her as soon as I get home. I’m doing a private screening in Georgia and so I get to take her, and I cannot wait to pick our seat out, me, her and her dad. We are going to go watch the movie with a room full of family and friends.”

title: Drew Barrymore experiences hot flash during talk show segment: 'They come out of nowhere'
summary: Drew Barrymore experienced another hot flash during a segment on "The Drew Barrymore Show."
story: Drew Barrymore had to pause a segment of  "The Drew Barrymore Show" so she could fan herself down while she experienced a hot flash.

A recent episode of the daytime talk show kicked off by showing Barrymore's co-stars Ross Mathews and Valerie Bertinelli laughing as they helped fan her down as a segment about food expiration labels with Danny Seo was just about to begin.
As Barrymore removed her plaid jacket, Mathews told viewers, “We’re fanning Drew down because -- "
“I’m experiencing a hot flash. It’s happening again. God, it’s so hot," Barrymore interjected.
“Oh my God, it’s like a hot blanket,” Bertinelli, 64, noted as she took Barrymore’s jacket from her.
“Like a thermos,” Mathews, 45, added.

A hot flash is a sudden warm feeling typically felt around the face, neck and chest that can happen to women around the time of menopause, according to the Mayo Clinic. Hot flashes can also cause blotchy skin, a faster heartbeat, anxiety and other symptoms.
“It’s just so weird that they come out of nowhere, you know?” Barrymore said. “I’m so lightheaded right now.”
Mathews then encouraged members of the studio audience to help fan Barrymore so she could cool down.
“I wish I could just start taking my clothes off, but that would get weird," the host joked.
Barrymore then returned to her segment about food label expiration dates with Seo, joking, "I feel like I’m having an expiration date, physically, right now.”
She kept up her sense of humor throughout the segment. When Mathews mentioned food that's kept in a refrigerator, Barrymore quipped, “A fridge, God, I’d love a fridge right now.”
It's not the first time Barrymore has dealt with a hot flash on the air.
She experienced the first hot flash of her life while interviewing "Murder Mystery" franchise stars Jennifer Aniston and Adam Sandler on her show in March 2023.
“I’m so hot. I think I’m having one of my first perimenopause hot flashes,” a shocked Barrymore told Aniston and Sandler while removing her jacket.
“For the first time, I think I’m having my first hot flash!” she added.
“Oh, I’m so honored!” joked Aniston, who leaned in to adjust Barrymore’s clip-on microphone.
Barrymore apologized as Aniston caressed the back of her neck to soothe her.
“Do you feel this?” Barrymore asked, referring to her body’s suddenly rising temperature.
When Sandler mentioned that he believed that hot flashes bring on “heavy” mood swings, Barrymore jokingly glared at him.
“Here it is!” Sandler yelled, as the audience laughed.
Barrymore’s fans praised her for not cutting her hot flash out of the broadcast of her show.
“Thank you for helping to normalize talking openly about perimenopause and menopause,” wrote one.
“When your body decides to evolve on TV. An historic moment,” someone else commented.

title: Why 'The White Lotus' composer is leaving the show after Season 3
summary: Why the "The White Lotus" composer Cristobal Tapia de Veer is leaving the HBO show after Season 3 due to clashes with Mike White.
story: "The White Lotus" composer Cristobal Tapia de Veer is leaving the HBO anthology series after experiencing creative disagreements with the show's team since Season 1, he told the New York Times in a new interview.
“The White Lotus” theme song has been composed by Tapia de Veer since Season 1, and it's become one of the hallmarks of the show.

The first two theme songs featured unique spins on a similar melody, composed of a series of trilling vocals, with the first striking an ominous, tropical tone and the second, a vivacious, Italian beat.

But when Season 3 premiered Feb. 16, some viewers checking in to "The White Lotus" expressed initial disappointment at the new theme song. Season 3's song, titled "Enlightenment," shirked the familiar vocals for an ethereal, instrument driven song that divided fans — with some describing it as "spellbinding" and others demanding "justice."
“Jail for whoever made the decision to change ‘White Lotus’ theme song,” one person wrote on TikTok as the opening credits played on a TV.
“My disappointment when I didn’t hear this theme song,” another said. “Okay I was ready to dance... I don’t like this new theme song.”

Tapia de Veer reacted to the backlash while speaking with the Times for an article that published April 2, noting of the vocals, "I don’t think everybody was really aware of how attached people were to the ooh-loo-loo-loos."

He said after the season premiered, "I had TMZ calling me, even people from England and from France, because they wanted some kind of statement about the theme. People are furious about the change of the theme, and I thought that was interesting."
Tapia de Veer said he responded by telling a producer to give fans an extended version of the theme song, "because people will explode if they realize that it was going there anyway."
"He thought it was a good idea. But then Mike (White, show creator and writer) cut that — he wasn’t happy about that," Tapia de Veer said.
TODAY.com has reached out to HBO and representatives for White for comment but did not immediately hear back.
On March 19, Tapia de Veer uploaded the uncut version to his YouTube channel anyway.
"I mean, at that point, we already had our last fight forever, I think. So he was just saying no to anything. So I just uploaded that to my YouTube," he told the Times.
The comment section of the video is filled with praise for the longer version of the theme song.
